event: Invention of the wheel and plough in Mesopotamia (present-day Iraq); invention of the sail in Egypt: three fundamental inventions for trade, agriculture and exploration
Invention of writing in Mesopotamia: the means to record and understand human history
Founding of the first cities in Sumeria (present-day Iraq): origin of modern social and administrative structures
Building of the Great Pyramid.
Modern alphabet invented: the essential means of communication of complex concepts and culture
Beginning of Greek civilisation: essential to Western heritage and the root of mathematics, philosophy, political thinking and medicine
Consensus for the Fall of Troy (if there was a Trojan War).
The Judean King David captures Jerusalem.
Legendary start of the Ancient Olympics.
First Olympiad in Greece.
Foundation of Rome: the Roman Empire is a pillar of the modern age, producing ideas on justice, law, engineering and warfare
Legendary founding of Rome.
Invention of ironworking: metallurgy is the key to further technical, economic and military developments
Babylonian King Nebuchadnezzar conquers Jerusalem and brings the Judean king and thousands of citizens of Judea back to Babylon with him.
Greek philosopher Thales of Miletus successfully predicts a solar eclipse on May 28.
Birth of Confucius, the founder of one of the world's major philosophical systems
Cyrus the Great establishes the Achaemenid dynasty of the Persian Empire.
Greeks defeated the Persians at the Battle of Marathon.Battle of Marathon: the Greeks repel a Persian invasion, securing the survival of Greek culture and science
Greeks win against the Persians in Battle of Marathon.
Birth of Buddha, founder of one of the world's major religions
Indian philosopher Siddhartha Gautama Buddha dies and his followers begin to organize a religious movement based on his teachings.
The period of Aristotle and Plato.
Philip's son Alexander the Great rules Macedonia.
Alexander fights and wins against the Persians at the Battle of Granicus in Anatolia.
Macedonian forces under Alexander defeat the Persians at the Battle of Issus.
Egypt conquered by Alexander.
Alexander conquers Egypt, founds Alexandria, and installs a Greek government but leaves the next year.
At the Battle of Gaugamela, Alexander defeats the Persian king Darius III.
Empire of Alexander the Great reaches into India: the first example of a long-term and often violent interrelationship between Europe and Asia
Alexander reaches the limit of his expansion, winning the Battle of the Hydaspes in the northern Punjab region of what is today Pakistan.
The Mauryan empire in India is founded by Chandragupta Maurya, the first ruler to unite most of the Indian subcontinent.
Alexander dies, and his empire falls apart as his generals, the diadochi, battle one another for supremacy.
Alexander dies at Babylon.
The first Greek pharaoh of Egypt, Ptolemy I, takes over the reins and establishes the Ptolemaic dynasty.
Greek mathematician Eratosthenes measures the Earth's circumference.
Work on the Great Wall of China begins.
Hannibal is defeated by Rome: the victory is essential to secure the survival and expansion of Roman civilisation
Roman leaders Pompey, Crassus, and Julius Caesar form the First Triumvirate.
details: The First Triumvirate was an informal alliance among three prominent politicians in the late Roman Republic: Gaius Julius Caesar, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus and Marcus  Crassus.

event: Julius Ceasar attacks Great Britain.
Julius Caesar invades Britain.
Caesar crosses the Rubicon, precipitating the Roman Civil War.
Battle of Pharsalus (Ceaser vs Pompey)
details: The Battle of Pharsalus was the decisive battle of Caesar's Civil War fought on 9 August 48 BC near Pharsalus in central Greece. Julius Caesar and his allies formed up opposite the army of the Roman Republic under the command of Pompey. Pompey had the backing of a majority of Roman senators and his army significantly outnumbered the veteran Caesarian legions  but Pompey lost fled to Egypt and was murdered there.

event: On the Ides of March (March 15), Caesar is assassinated.
The 2nd Triumvirate, that of Marc Antony, Octavian, and M Aemillius Lepidus, is established.
Founding of the Roman Empire: this is the start of the classic period of Roman domination in Europe and the Mediterranean
Birth of Jesus Christ, founder of the many branches of Christianity. The exact date is disputed
Crucifixion of Jesus Christ.
Judean philosopher Jesus is executed by Rome and his followers continue.
details: According to the canonical gospels, Jesus was arrested and tried by the Sanhedrin, and then by Pontius Pilate, who sentenced him to be scourged, and finally crucified by the Romans
mnemonic: Believed to be April 3, 33. Friday a day of lunar eclipse.

event: Rome burns while Nero (supposedly) fiddles.
details: The popular legend that Nero played the fiddle while Rome burned "is at least partly a literary construct of Flavian propaganda. Nero was egotistical, unpopular and built a temple to himself on the site of the fire, leading to this assertion about him "fiddling."
mnemonic: Fire started in 64. Nero was done by 68

event: Mount Vesuvius erupts burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum.
details: In the autumn of 79 AD, Mount Vesuvius violently spewed forth a deadly cloud of super-heated gases to a height of 33 km (21 mi), ejecting molten rock, pulverized pumice and hot ash, ultimately releasing 100,000 times the thermal energy of the Hiroshima bomb.
mnemonic: Emperor Titus started his rule in 79, and a coin found in Pompeii was from that time.

event: First use of modern paper: this replaced stone, slate, papyrus and vellum as a cheap and convenient medium
Roman soldiers begin building Hadrian's Wall, a defensive structure that will eventually stretch 70 miles across Northern England and marks the northern limit of the empire in Great Britain.
details: Hadrian's Wall is a former defensive fortification of the Roman province of Britannia, begun in AD 122 in the reign of the emperor Hadrian
mnemonic: In 122, Hadrian (emperor since 117) decided to end the empire's expansion, and commissioned the wall.

event: Unification of China under the Western Chin dynasty creates the political shape of modern China
Roman Emperor Constantine converts to Christianity: this made it possible for Christianity to spread across Europe
Constantine the Great establishes his capital at Byzantium (Constantinople).
details: In 324, the ancient city of Byzantium was renamed "New Rome" and declared the new capital of the Roman Empire by Emperor Constantine the Great
mnemonic: In 324, Byzantium was chosen as the capital, because of the strategic importance of the East.

event: Huns' invasion of Europe.
Arguably, the western Roman Empire ends when Emperor Romulus Augustulus is removed from office.
details: In 476, the Germanic leader Odoacer staged a revolt and deposed the Emperor Romulus Augustulus. From then on, no Roman emperor would ever again rule from a post in Italy, leading many to cite 476 as the year the Western Empire suffered its deathblow.
mnemonic: Exactly 1300 years after the end of the Roman empire, America gains independence.

event: Fall of the Roman Empire in the West ends 800 years of Roman hegemony. The creation of moderen Europe begins
St Benedict of Nursia, Italy founded the Benedictine order
details: The monastery at Subiaco in Italy, established by Benedict of Nursia c.529, was the first of the dozen monasteries he founded

event: Prophet Mohammed born at Mecca.
Birth of Muhammad, founder of one of the world's great religions
Flight of Mohammed from Mecca to Madina.
Death of Mohammed; Beginning of Hijiri Era.
Arabs invade Spain.
Printing invented in China: an essential step in mass communication/ administration/cultural dissemination
Charlemagne crowned Emperor of the new Western Empire. This marked the point at which Europe began to reintegrate. The Holy Roman Empire lasts for 1,000 years
Vikings founded Russia - settling in Kiev
details: Oleg of Novgorod is credited with seizing power in Kiev (Kyiv), and he was the supreme ruler of the Rus' from 882 to 912.

event: Lief Erikson believed to have set foot in North America
details: Leif Erikson was a Norse explorer who is thought to have been the first European to have set foot on continental   North America, approximately half a millennium before   Christopher Columbus

event: Schism of Greek and Latin Christian Churches divides Christianity permanently into two geographical and denominational halves
The battle of Hastings and the Norman conquest
Norman invasion of England; Victory of William the Conquerer over the English King Harold II at Hastings.
Tower of London was built
details: Work on the White Tower which gives the whole castle its name is usually considered to have begun in 1078

event: First university founded in Bologna, Italy: the start of a modern conception of higher learning and universal knowledge
The first crusade.
details: The First Crusade (1096-1099) was the first of a series of religious wars, or Crusades, initiated, supported and at times directed by the Latin Church in the medieval period.

event: The First Crusade is decreed. The start of European Christian knights mounting successive military campaigns in attempts to conquer the Holy Land.
University of Paris established in France.
details: In 1150, the future University of Paris was a student-teacher corporation operating as an annex of the Notre-Dame cathedral school

event: Genghis Khan begins his conquest of Asia. This has a major impact on Asian development and the movement of peoples
Magna Carta signed by King John at Runnymede: this is the origin of the modern concept of constitutional rule
Marco Polo sets off for Asia, with his father and uncle.
details: Marco Polo was an explorer, and writer who travelled through Asia along the Silk Road between 1271 and 1295. His travels are recorded in   The Travels of Marco Polo

event: Roger Bacon invents gunpowder.
The battle of Bannockburn in which the Scottish leader Robert the Bruce took on the English king Edward II in a pivotal conflict in Scotland's fight for independence.
The Hundred years War broke out.
England faces Black Death Plague.
details: The summer of 1348 saw the first outbreak of the bubonic plague in England, leading to an epidemic of huge proportions. The disease is estimated to have killed between a third and a half of the population    a devastating and unprecedented death rate.

event: Turks captured Constantinople; Renaissance in Europe.
Fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks: Almost 500 years of Turkish domination of the Eastern Mediterranean, North Africa and the Middle East begins
First book printed with moveable type: Johannes Gutenberg's revolution in printing technology makes mass-market reading possible
mnemonic: The Fall of Constantinople and Guttenberg happened around the same time. ~2 years of each other

event: Leonard da Vinci draws the "Vitruvian Man" showing proportions of the human body.
details: The drawing, which is in ink on paper, depicts a man in two superimposed positions with his arms and legs apart and inscribed in a circle and square.

event: Discovery of America by Columbus.
Christopher Columbus discovers the New World, bringing the Americas into a global trading/cultural system
Sea-route to India discovered by Vasco-de-Gama.
Invention of the watch: essential to a modern economy and administration, this introduces the concept of regular timekeeping
Martin Luther launches the Reformation. It is the start of Protestant Christianity and the idea of religious individualism
mnemonic: Gutterberg's printing press (~1450) gave wider access to the Bible, which in turn led to alternative interpretations, including that of Martin Luther, whose "95 Theses" a document printed by the hundred-thousand sparked the Protestant Reformation.

event: Cortes begins his conquest of South America, which becomes part of the wider world economic and political system
The Mughals empire begings. The Mughals from Central Asia began to rule parts of India
Copernicus publishes his Heliocentric theory -- that planents revolve around the sun
details: This model positioned the Sun at the center of the Universe, motionless, with Earth and the other planets orbiting around it in circular paths, modified by epicycles, and at uniform speeds. The Copernican model displaced the geocentric model of Ptolemy that had prevailed for centuries, which had placed Earth at the center of the Universe.

event: William Shakespeare is born: his plays make fundamental statements about the human condition
Spanish Armada defeated.
British East India Company established in India.
Death of Queen Elizabeth I.
details: Her reign is famous for the defeat of the Armada, and for successful raids against the Spanish. Elizabeth established an English church that helped shape a national identity and remains in place today

event: Kepler discovers that planets have elliptical orbits
details: Kepler discovered that the orbit of Mars was an ellipse. In 1609 he published Astronomia Nova, delineating his discoveries, which are now called Kepler's first two laws of planetary motion.

event: Mayflower arrives in America -- Pilgrims arrived at Cape Cod, carrying passengers from England.
details: Mayflower arrived in New England on November 11, 1620 after a voyage of 66 days. Although the Pilgrims had originally intended to settle near the Hudson River in New York, dangerous shoals and poor winds forced the ship to seek shelter at Cape Cod.
mnemonic: The puritans wanted to "purify" England's Anglician church. QE1 and King James (in the early 1600's) "Persecuted" them.

event: Galileo publishes a book claiming that the planets moved around the sun (Heliocentric), and angering the then pope.
details: In 1632 Galileo angered the Pope when he published a book in which he openly stated that the Earth was moving around the Sun. He was put on trial by the Inquisition in Rome, where he was found suspect of heresy, and forced to say that all of his findings were wrong

event: Execution of Charles I.
Thomas Hobbes's Leviathan is published: this is the origin of the modern idea of civil society, equality before the law and egoistic individualism
Monarchy restored in England.
The Great Plague of England.
The Great Fire of London
details: The city was essentially medieval in its street plan, an overcrowded warren of narrow, winding, cobbled alleys. Building with wood and roofing with thatch had been prohibited for centuries, but these cheap materials continued to be used.
mnemonic: The 1666 fire, in essense ended "Medieval" London, and led to important restructuring. Remember, it came 1 year after the Great Plague.

event: Glorious Revolution in England.
Isaac Newton publishes Principia Mathematica, the foundation of modern physics
Battle of Blenheim.
Union of England and Scotland.
Euler solves the "Seven Bridges of Kongsberg" problem, the start of the Graph Theory branch of mathematics.
details: In 1735, Euler presented a solution to the problem known as the Seven Bridges of K  nigsberg.[73] The city of K  nigsberg, Prussia was set on the Pregel River, and included two large islands that were connected to each other and the mainland by seven bridges. The problem is to decide whether it is possible to follow a path that crosses each bridge exactly once and returns to the starting point. It is not possible. This solution is considered to be the first theorem of graph theory

event: Declaration of American Independence.
Adam Smith publishes the Wealth of Nation, a fundament work in Classical Economics
details: The central thesis of Smith's "The Wealth of Nations" is th at our individual need to fulfill self-interest results in societal benefit, in what is known as his "invisible hand".

event: American Declaration of Independence determines the political evolution of the New World and the rise of American power
French Revolution marks a fundamental break with the tradition of monarchy; the 'rights of man' are enshrined
French Revolution; George Washington elected the first President of America.
Invention of the Internal Combustion Engine
details: 1794, Robert Street patented an internal combustion engine, which was also the first to use liquid fuel, and built an engine around that time.

event: Dr Jenner create the first-ever Vaccine
details: On 14 May 1796, Jenner tested his hypothesis by inoculating James Phipps, an eight-year-old boy who was the son of Jenner's gardener

event: Start of the Lewis & Clark expedition, in America.
details: The Lewis and Clark Expedition from August 31, 1803, to September 25, 1806, also known as the Corps of Discovery Expedition, was the United States expedition to cross the newly acquired western portion of the country after the Louisiana Purchase.
mnemonic: It took exactly 30 years after America independence for a team to cross from the East coast to the west coast.

event: Battle of Trafalagar and Nelson's death.
Battle of Waterloo: the Napoleonic Empire ends, and with it Napoleon's ambition to rule and reform all of Europe
Battle of Waterloo; Napolean exiled to St. Helena.
Death of Napolean.
Rocket steam locomotive built, marking the start of the railway age of cheap, fast land transport
Reforms Bill passed in England.
Queen Victoria's accession to the throne of England.
The first use of nitrous gas for Anesthesia by Dr. Horace Wells.
details: In 1844, Dr.  Wells conducted a trial on himself by inhaling nitrous oxide and having John Riggs extract a tooth.[5] Upon a successful trial where he did not feel any pain, Wells went on to use nitrous oxide on at least 12 other patients in his office.

event: Publication of Darwin's The Origin of Species. His theory of evolution transforms the view of Man and his environment, and belief in God
details: Published on 24 November 1859, is a work of scientific literature by Charles Darwin that is considered to be the foundation of evolutionary biology
mnemonic: Darwin conceived the ideas in 1839, and waited 20 years for various reasons.

event: Drilling of the first modern oil well.  At Titusville, Penn., Col. Edwin Drake drilled the first successful well through rock and produced crude oil
Beginning of the American Civil War.
Slavery abolished in USA
General Robert E. Lee surrendered his 28,000 Confederate troops to Union General Ulysses S. Grant, effectively ending the American Civil War
Assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
Purchase of Alaska - US buys Alaska from Russia.
details: Secretary of State William Seward made the purchase which also ended Russia's presence in North America and ensured U.S. access to the Pacific northern rim.

event: Opening of the Suez Canal for traffic.
"Dr. Livingstone, I presume": US journalist Stanley finds explorer Dr. Livingstone
details: After nearly eight months Stanley found Livingstone in Ujiji, a small village on the shore of Lake Tanganyika on November 10, 1871.
mnemonic: Slave trade ended ~1850, and colonization of Congo happened in 1885. This episode was right in between.

event: Alexander Graham Bell Invents the telephone
details: On March 10, 1876,  Bell spoke the sentence "Mr. WatsonCome hereI want to see you" into the liquid transmitter and the first phone call was made.
mnemonic: Exactly 100 years after the US declared Independence, the telephone showed up!

event: Edison invents the electric light bulb
details: Light bulbs with a carbon filament were first demonstrated by Edison in October 1879
mnemonic: The telephone showed up 3 years before the bulb!

event: Eruption of Krakatoa
details: over 70% of the island of Krakatoa and its surrounding archipelago were destroyed as it collapsed into a caldera.

event: Benz develops first petrol-driven car, starting the most profound technical and social revolution of the modern age
New Zealand introduces unrestricted women's suffrage. At this point women win the principle of full political equality
Roentgen discovered X-Rays.
mnemonic: X-Rays and Radio discovered/invented in the same year.

event: Marconi invented the radio for wireless transmission
details: Marconi transmitted radio signals for about 1.5 miles (2.4 km) at the end of 1895
mnemonic: X-Rays and Radio discovered/invented in the same year.

event: The Wright brothers invent the first powered aircraft.
details: The Wrights finally took to the air on December 17, 1903, making two flights each from level ground into a freezing headwind gusting to 27 miles per hour (43 km/h)

event: Russo-Japan war.
mnemonic: This was was fought between the Empire of Japan and the Russian Empire during 1904 and 1905 over rival imperial ambitions in Manchuria and the Korean Empire

event: Japan defeated Russia; Discovery of the theory of Relativity by Einstein.
Einstein's theory of special relativity published. It transforms the nature of modern physical knowledge
Roald Amundsen becomes the first person to reach the South Pole.
details: The first ever expedition to reach the geographic Southern Pole was led by the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen. He and four others arrived at the pole on 14 December 1911, five weeks ahead of a British party led by Robert Falcon Scott as part of the Terra Nova Expedition.
mnemonic: The North Pole was reached in 1909. So Amundsen changed his plans to head to the South Pole in 1911

event: Chinese Revolution.
Republic of China established.
Beginning of World War I.
Russian Revolution creates the first successful, long-term revolutionary state
End of the First World War. The Habsburg and Ottoman empires collapse; maps of Europe and the Middle East are redrawn
End of World War I.
Treaty of Versailles signed.
Formation of the League of Nations.
Turkey declared Republic.
Invetion of Television
details: Scottish inventor John Logie Baird, in 1926, demonstrated the transmission of an image of a face in motion by radio. This is widely regarded as the world's first public television demonstration
mnemonic: Priorities! Humans invented a TV 2 years before they discovered Penicillin.

event: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin
details: In 1928 Dr Alexander Fleming returned from a holiday to find mould growing on a Petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria. He noticed the mould seemed to be preventing the bacteria around it from growing. He soon identified that the mould produced a self-defence chemical that could kill bacteria.

event: Discovery of planet Pluto
details: Tombaugh discovered the tiny, distant planet by use of a new astronomic technique of photographic plates combined with a blink microscope.

event: Hitler became the Chancellor of Germany.
Beginning of the Spanish Civil War.
World War II begins.
Outbreak of Second World War: 50 million die worldwide from 1939-45 in the world's largest and most deadly conflict, which ends the long age of imperialisms
Russia invaded by Hitler; Pearl Harbour invaded by Japan.
when the first nuclear bomb is detonated, mankind develops the means to destroy itself
End of Second World War;
Establishment of UNO; End of World War II; Hiroshima and Nagasaki experience the first dropping of the Atom Bomb; Death of President Roosevelt.
Civil War in China.
Burma and Ceylon get independence.
Communist China founded: China is created as a single territorial unit with a common administration and a modernising economy
Indonesia gets independence;
The Communists capture power in China.
General Eisenhower elected as the American President.
Death of Stalin; Mt. Everest conquered for the first time.
Military Aid Pact between China and Pakistan;
Austria gets independence; Bandung Conference.
Suez Canal nationalised by President Nasser; Egypt attacked by the forces of Britain, France and Israel.
First artificial satellite launched by Russia.
Egypt and Syria united and renamed United Arab Republic (UAR)
Chinese capture Tibet; Dalai Lama flees to India; Sputnik launched by Russia.
Invention of the silicon chip is the major technical invention of the past century, making possible the computer age
Election of John F. Kennedy as President of USA
First contraceptive pill made available for women, who can now make their own biological choices about reproduction
Explosion of an atom bomb device by France;
Yuri Gagarin of USSR becomes the first spaceman.
Malaysia established
Partial Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty signed;
John F. Kennedy assassinated.
Discovery of the Universe's Cosmic microwave Background Radiation
details: In 1964 while using the Horn Antenna, Penzias and Wilson stumbled on the microwave background radiation that permeates the universe.

event: Singapore becomes the sovereign independent nation
Death of Sir Winston Churchill
Outbreak of the Second Indo-Pak war, also called the "Second Kashmir War"
Tashkent Pact; A Russian aircraft lands on moon.
Chinese explode hydrogen bomb; Arab-Israel War; Suez Canal closed.
Outbreak of Indo-Pak war; Birth of Bangladesh; Surrender of 93,000 Pakistani troops; Khruschev died; Z.A. Bhutto new President of Pakistan.

Sheikh Mujibur Rahman freed from Pakistani Jail and assumed the office of P.M. Bangladesh; Nixon of USA visited China; King Mahendra of Nepal died; USA and the USSR sign Strategic Arms Limitations Treaty.
Outbreak of fourth Arab-Israeli war; Fourth non-aligned summit in Algiers.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, President of Bangladesh assassinated; King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, assassinated; Suez Canal reopened; Red Cross force Cambodia Government to Surrender.
Chou-En Lai, P.M. of China, died; Seychelles gets independence; Viking I lands on Mars; Mao Tse-tung died; Jimmy Carter elected President of USA

Agreement between Israel and Egypt; Vietnam attacked Cambodia; Z.A. Bhutto, former P.M. of Pakistan, sentenced to death; Bloody coup in Afghanistan; Mohammed Daoud assassinated; World's first test-tube baby born.
Mrs. Margaret Thatcher is the first woman P.M. of Britain.
Chinese aggression in Vietnam;
Cambodian rebels grab power in Pnom Penh
Mr. Z.A. Bhutto hanged
War starts between Iran and Iraq
Ronald Reagon elected USA President.

Falklands, captured by Argentina; Israel attacks South Lebanon; Argentina forces surrender to British; P.L.O. Chief Yesser Arafat leaves Beirut; Bashir Gemyel, the President elect of Lebanon, assassinated; Soviet President breathes his last.
US attacks Grenada; USA withdraws from UNESCO.
Vietnam withdraws troops from Kampuchia.
India gets Presidentship of the UN Security Council
Soviet President Mr. Konstantin Chernenko dies
American air attack on Libya.
Nuclear tests by USSR; Fresh proposal by Gorbachev; Group 77 meet at Havana; Unsuccessful military coup in Philippines, Prime Minister of Lebanon killed.
Nearly 1,00,000 people killed in earthquake in Armenia.
Arafat declares on independent state of Palestine,
George Bush elected President of USA,
WHO observes 7th of April as no smoking day, French President re-elected, Gen. Zia-ul-Haq killed in plane crash, Quake kills about 1,000 people in Bihar (India),
The UN Peace keeping force starts implementation of UN Resolution 435 for the independence of  Namibia.
Collapse of Communist regimes in Europe: marks the end of the long communist experiment; Asian communism is also transformed.

The Panamanian President surrenders to the United States. South Africa lifts lean on African National Congress. Lithuania declares independence from the Soviet Union. Namibia becomes a free nation. Iraq overruns Kuwait. East and West Germanys unite.
War breaks out in the Gulf when Iraq invades Kuwait, resulting in the defeat of Iraq.
5 new members of security council START II treaty between Russian & US Presidents, Security Council resolution on Angola, Emergency in Zambia, Elections in Australia.
South Africa emerged from aparthied regime with Nelson Mandela as its president. GATT treaty signed to create World Trade Organisation (WTO).
WTO comes into existence. Nuclear test by France. Balkan peace accord signed.
Clinton re-elected US President.
India refuses to sign CTBT.
Taliban capture Kabul and execute former communist President Najibullah.
Dolly the sheep becomes the first mammal to be cloned from an adult cell.
details: Her birth proved that specialised cells could be used to create an exact copy of the animal they came from. This knowledge changed what scientists thought was possible and opened up a lot of possibilities in biology and medicine, including the development of personalised stem cells known as iPS cells.

event: Kofi Annan new UN Secretary General.
Shekh Hasina Wajed new PM of Bangladesh.
Tony Blair back in power in UK. Mohd. Khatami elected president of Iran. Hong Kong goes back to China after 99 year British rule.
Indonesian President Suharto resigns. Pakistan test fires `Gauri' missile. US President Clinton faces impeachment.
Yugoslavia accepts a peace plan for Kosovo.
